partial_orders.reason: Both edits reference the exact same symbol 'encoding' within the same function '_get_file_contents'. Edit 0 removes the 'encoding' parameter from the function signature, and Edit 1 removes the usage of that same 'encoding' parameter in the function body. These edits are part of a single refactoring task to remove the encoding parameter entirely. After making either edit, the other becomes the immediate next step to maintain code consistency - if you remove the parameter from the signature, you must remove its usage in the body, and vice versa. Both edits can be staged in either order without causing parse errors.

Edit 0 removes the 'encoding' parameter from the _get_file_contents method signature, while Edit 1 updates a call site to remove the encoding parameter and handle encoding manually with to_text(). These edits reference the exact same method symbol (_get_file_contents) and form a signature-caller relationship. After making either edit, the other becomes the immediate next step to maintain code consistency - if you change the signature without updating the caller, you get a TypeError, and if you update the caller without changing the signature, the encoding parameter becomes unused. Both edits can be staged in either order without parse errors, making this bi-directional.

Edit 0 changes the _get_file_contents method to return raw bytes instead of decoded text (removing the to_text call and encoding parameter usage). Edit 1 updates a caller of this same method to handle the new return type by removing the encoding parameter from the call and adding its own to_text conversion. These edits reference the exact same method (_get_file_contents) and form a signature-caller relationship where the method signature change necessitates updating the call site to handle the new return type. This is a direct code dependency where making either edit creates an immediate prompt for the other.
